awd_titl_txt: SHF: Medium: Conquering MPSoC Complexity with Principles of a Self-Aware Information Processing Factory
awd_abstract_narration:
Self-aware systems are reactive and  proactive, and capable of thinking outside the box, thereby coping with unforeseen situations in a dependable manner, unlike existing systems  that are designed subject to deterministic procedural specifications. Self-awareness is a critical feature for future cyber-physical systems which must cope with scenarios that were not conceived when they were developed. This project will explore directions for overhead-efficient self-aware HW/SW systems while guaranteeing critical properties such as real-time behaviors, resilience, security, and energy efficiency.  The project's study of self-awareness principles to enable autonomy in the face of dynamic and unforeseen changes will significantly impact a wide range of cyber physical application domains that critically depend on high-performance, low power and dependable computing. These systems play a pivotal role for conquering key societal challenges in healthcare, safety, transportation and industrial automation. The parallel collaborative nature of this project with German partners at TU Braunschweig and TU Munich  will train a diverse group of students and researchers and enrich their learning experiences by exposing them to the challenges of delivering autonomous IT services in different societal and international contexts.  The project will also motivate  undergraduate and underrepresented students to pursue research and graduate studies.  Students will benefit tremendously from exposure to and involvement in the design of new design and development paradigms for introducing cognition into a multi-tiered CPS and IoT infrastructure.

The project introduces the notion of a self-aware Information Processing Factory (IPF) as a step towards autonomous Multi-Processor System-on-Chip (MPSoC) platforms in Cyber-Physical Systems (CPS) and the Internet of Things (IoT).  The objective is to synergistically merge the situational flexibility of self-aware/self-organizing emergence with the predictability of hierarchical top-down control in a holistic multi-layer approach, resembling an Information Processing Factory. Sensory information at multiple scales -- on-chip, run-time systems, applications -- will be monitored, fused, and interpreted intelligently to assess health status, mitigate adverse effects, and optimize system goals of the MPSoC using a novel hierarchy of self-aware control loops that can both manage complexity, as well as achieve guarantees.  Additionally, a unique scalable distributed run-time verification architecture will enable hardware-supported cross-layer monitoring of parametric specifications. The resulting approach synergistically covers the multi-tiered abstraction hierarchy from low-level VLSI circuits to runtime OS and dynamic application software. The  project complements efforts at TU Braunschweig and TU Munich in Germany, and leverages research efforts on self-awareness and self-organization at the hardware and software layers of cyber physical multicore platforms.

por.por_cntn:
Self-aware systems cope with unforeseen situations in a dependable manner by combining reactive and proactive processes, unlike existing systems that are designed subject to deterministic procedural specifications. Self-awareness is a critical feature for future cyber-physical systems which must cope with scenarios that were not conceived when they were developed. This project explored directions for overhead-efficient self-aware hardware/software systems while guaranteeing critical properties such as real-time behaviors, resilience, security, and energy efficiency. The project introduced the notion of a self-aware Information Processing Factory (IPF) as a step towards autonomous Multi-Processor System-on-Chip (MPSoC) platforms in Cyber-Physical Systems (CPS) and the Internet of Things (IoT). The objective was to synergistically merge the situational flexibility of self-aware/self-organizing emergence with the predictability of hierarchical top-down control in a holistic multi-layer approach, resembling an Information Processing Factory. Sensory information at multiple scales - on-chip, run-time systems, applications - were monitored, fused, and interpreted intelligently to assess health status, mitigate adverse effects, and optimize system goals of the MPSoC using a novel hierarchy of self-aware control loops that both manage complexity, as well as to achieve guarantees. Additionally, a unique scalable distributed run-time verification architecture was proposed to enable hardware-supported cross-layer monitoring of parametric specifications. The resulting IPF approach synergistically covers the multi-tiered abstraction hierarchy from low-level VLSI circuits to runtime OS and dynamic application software. The IPF project was also executed in parallel with a collaborative research effort with German partners at TU Braunschweig (TUB) and TU Munich (TUM), exposing students and researchers to the challenges of delivering autonomous IT services in different societal and international contexts.

Intellectual Outcomes

The IPF project made several conceptual advances in applying self-awareness principles in the contexts of: self-aware hierarchical and supervisory control for adaptive resource management; adaptive, reflective middleware for computing systems; adaptive system reconfiguration for dynamic scenarios in autonomous platforms; proactive management of emergent behaviors in autonomous computing platforms; runtime monitoring and verification for emergent behaviors; and failure prediction and safety assurances for emergent behaviors.  The techniques for self-aware supervisory control were applied to manage both computing as well as memory resources,  on platforms ranging from single core to multicore processors.  Furthermore, the applications executing on these platforms emulated realistic execution constraints including a mix of best-effort and critical behaviors, as well as multiple end-to-end  (sensor-to-actuator) pipelined behaviors for autonomous systems that must be mapped onto these platforms while satisfying adaptive timing, energy and safety requirements. Novel approaches were developed to enable adaptive system reconfiguration for dynamic deadlines in autonomous driving, while minimizing energy consumption. Several advances were made in dealing with yet-unforeseen emergent behaviors at runtime, including  predicting failures in embedded systems using long short-term inference, NUVA/TAL - a hardware/software infrastructure to support runtime monitoring, property mining, and runtime property verification, and the SAFER framework that generates safety assurances for emergent behaviors via a model that learns safe execution based on execution traces from the code.  The approaches developed in the IPF project were validated on a wide range of realistic design exemplars spanning small form-factor IoT devices (e.g., pacemakers), single CPS platforms (e.g., autonomous vehicles), to large system-of-systems (e.g., truck platooning).  Many of these design exemplars were developed jointly with our German partners at TUB and TUM.

Broader Impact

The IPF project addressed societal demands for safety, reliability, and predictability of IoT, embedded and autonomous systems by providing operational autonomy in response to the explosion of system complexity that continues to grow in the face of newer end-to-end applications. Researchers currently design autonomous systems assuming that multiple well-written applications execute predictably on MPSoC platforms, but fail to validate these coordinated applications across the entire computing stack.  The IPF project disseminated new concepts, algorithms, software and benchmarks  addressing these issues. Examples of artifacts include the Chauffeur benchmark suite for autonomous vehicles [1] and the MARS software infrastructure for building adaptive, self-aware CPS systems [2].  The IPF project trained a large group of researchers (1 postdoctoral scholar, 6 PhDs, and 23 undergraduates) in conceptual, theoretical and practical aspects of deploying self-awareness principles for safe and adaptive system design.  The IPF research team also disseminated research results through a large body of publications (16 Journal articles, 13 conference papers and 2 book chapters), many of which were jointly coauthored by the German partners at TUB and TUM. Finally, the unique parallel, international collaborative nature of this project trained a diverse group of students and researchers that enriched their learning experiences by exposing them to the challenges of delivering autonomous IT services in diﬀerent societal and international contexts.

[1] Chauffeur open source release:  Benchmark Suite for Design and End-to-End Analysis of Self-Driving Vehicles on Embedded Systems: https://github.com/duttresearchgroup/Chauffeur

[2] MARS (Middleware for Adaptive Reflective Systems) open source release https://github.com/duttresearchgroup/MARS
